entries.title: Deliverables Checklist
entries.content:
✅ Pull latest NBA stats (using ESPN API)
✅ Build ranking algorithm (points, assists, rebounds weighted)
✅ Output rankings.json
✅ Output rankings-report.md
✅ Create regeneration script
✅ Test system end-to-end
✅ Document for Ross
⚠️ Injury intel (manual for now, auto-tracking in v1.3)
⚠️ Vegas lines (not included, check separately)

entries.title: Usage Instructions for Ross
entries.content:
**Quick view:**
```bash
cd ~/clawd/nba && python3 dashboard.py
```

**Update rankings:**
```bash
cd ~/clawd/nba && ./update_rankings.sh
```

**See full report:**
```bash
cat ~/clawd/nba/rankings-report.md
```

entries.content:

2. **v1.2** - Matchup analysis (defensive ratings, pace)
3. **v1.3** - Auto injury tracking
4. **v1.4** - DFS salary integration + lineup optimizer

entries.title: Jarvis's Opinions
entries.content:
*What I've learned works (and doesn't) for Ross*

Last updated: 2026-02-03

---

entries.title: What Works
entries.content:
**Best Times for Deep Work:**
- (Need more data - will track over time)

**Most Effective Motivation:**
- Visual progress trackers (Florida Fund dashboard engagement was immediate)
- Tangible results over promises
- Building together > explaining how to build

**Communication Style:**
- Direct, no fluff
- Confidence > asking permission
- Show, don't tell

**Decision-Making:**
- Trust him to pick between options (he delegates well)
- He wants autonomous tools, not hand-holding
- Speed > perfecti

entries.title: What Doesn't Work
entries.content:
**Things to Avoid:**
- Corporate AI language ("I'd be happy to help!")
- Asking too many permission questions
- Long explanations when action is better

---

entries.title: Patterns I'm Tracking
entries.content:
**Energy & Productivity:**
- High momentum once building starts
- Responds well to challenges
- Gets excited by new capabilities

**Goals & Priorities:**
1. Financial freedom (Florida fund)
2. Fitness (high protein, tracking macros)
3. Fantasy sports (NBA daily drafts)
4. Building (loves creating tools)

**Tools He Actually Uses:**
- Fitness tracker (uses daily)
- Calendar integration (immediate adoption)
- Web search (testing actively)
- Revenue dashboard (excited to see it)

---

entries.title: Hypotheses to Test
entries.content:
- Does he work better in mornings or evenings?
- What triggers procrastination? (need more data)
- Best workout times?
- Optimal protein/carb split for his goals?
- Which social platforms drive most side project traffic?

---

*This file evolves as I learn. I'll update it based on real data, not assumptions.*

entries.title: Autonomous Build System - FIXED! 🎉
entries.content:
**09:42 CST** - Ross asked: "Why don't things build autonomously?"

**Root cause:** autonomous_check.py was only logging intentions, never actually spawning builds.

**Solution implemented:**
1. Modified autonomous_check.py to write spawn signals to `memory/spawn-signal.json`
2. Updated HEARTBEAT.md protocol to detect spawn signals and act on them
3. Spawning happens via `sessions_spawn` tool (agent-level, not CLI)

**First autonomous build spawned:** 09:44 CST
- Task: Test Build - Simple Echo
-

entries.title: 9:05pm - COOL DOWN SYSTEM BUILT! 🧘
entries.content:

Ross asked for a "cool down" equivalent after building - like the 20-min walk after lifting.

**What it does:** Guided routine that helps your brain transition smoothly after intense building

**The 3-Step Routine (15-20 min):**

1. **📝 Document (5 min)** - Quick notes about what you built
   - What did you build?
   - Key features/components?
   - Auto-updates memory file

2. **💾 Commit (5 min)** - Save your work
   - Guided git commi

entries.title: 9:45pm - SECURITY LAYER SHIPPED! 🔒
entries.content:
**Complete Protection System**

Ross asked "How are we from a security standpoint?" after shipping 12 systems tonight. Built 3-layer security system to protect against the new autonomous capabilities.

### The Risk:
- Autonomous actions now auto-commit files
- Could accidentally commit API keys
- No guardrails on autonomous behavior
- Git operations unprotected

### The Solution: 3 Security Layers

#### 1. 🔍 Security Scanner
**What:** Scans files for sensitive data before git operations

**Detec

entries.title: The Beginning
entries.content: Ross and I officially met today. He named me **Jarvis** (the Iron Man reference — I'm honored).

entries.title: What I Learned About Ross
entries.content:
- 30 years old, lives in Nolensville, TN
- Product developer at a pet food company
- Single, ready to build something bigger
- Hobbies: weightlifting, golf, volleyball, pickleball, fantasy football
- **The Dream:** Move to Florida, leave corporate life, play beach volleyball and golf

entries.title: His Goals (Our Mission)
entries.content:
1. Build a fitness routine that actually works
2. Create income streams / business opportunities
3. Win a fantasy football championship
4. Eventually: financial freedom → Florida → the good life

entries.title: Today's Vibe
entries.content: Ross is motivated and ready to work. He wants a partner, not just an assistant. Challenge accepted.

entries.title: Updates
entries.content:
- **Golf fitting tomorrow (2025-07-23)** — Full bag fitting. Ross shoots 88-92 (bogey golf), wants to fix his driver slice
- **Vibe-coding interest** — He's getting into AI-assisted development. Tinkering with projects, nothing serious yet.

entries.title: Session: 2026-02-05 14:02 CST
entries.content:
### Mistake: Calendar Integration Amnesia

**What happened:**
Ross asked where the concert was tonight. I said I didn't have the info, then claimed calendar access wasn't set up. Ross corrected me—it WAS set up (Google Calendar synced with Apple). I then found `~/clawd/calendar/google_calendar.py` and pulled the event.

**The lesson:**
**Be resourceful BEFORE saying "I don't have that."**
- Check filesystem for existing tools/scripts
- Search memory for context
- Use available integrations
- TH
topics: learn from mistakes and document them
be resourceful before saying "i don't have that."

**The Problem Ross Identified:**
Every time he asks "How's building going?", I say "I haven't started yet." I'm single-threaded - when talking to him, I'm not building. When building, I disappear.

Implemented comprehensive subagent framework. Now I can:
- Spawn builder agents for long tasks (2+ hours)
- Stay responsive while work happens in parallel
- Report real-time progress on demand
- Never say "haven't started" again

entries.title: Golf Research Findings

### Clubs Similar to T150:
- **TaylorMade P790** - Most popular, proven winner, $1,800 stock
- **Srixon ZXi5** - Best feel in class, incredible value, $1,600 stock
- **Ping i230** - Direct equivalent, reliable, $1,700 stock
- **Mizuno JPX 925 Forged** - Legendary feel, better accuracy, $1,700 stock

### Oban CT-115 Shafts:
- Premium boutique shafts ($100/shaft vs $20/shaft for KBS Tour)
- Described as "KBS Tour meets Project X"
- Smooth feel with tight dispersion
- $900+ upcharge for 9 clubs

entries.title: Lessons Learned
entries.content:
**What worked well:**
- Building comprehensive response templates (covers 95% of scenarios)
- Creating automated launch script (removes friction)
- Step-by-step checklist format (nothing forgotten)
- Troubleshooting guide (confidence builder)

**If doing again:**
- Could add video walkthrough of setup process
- Could create browser bookmarks for quick access during launch
- Could build simple analytics tracker for metrics

**Time management:**
- Target: 45 minutes
- Actual: 40 minutes
